events.text:
This is an extended example of a JSON dialogue system. 

The project is the same as the basic version but with a few more bells and whistles, including:
[item]Calling functions from within the JSON file via a function map
[item]Triggering timelines from a string using a function
[item]More formatting examples using the Formatting function
[item]Using the same Formatting function to replace words in the text with Global Variable values
[item]A very basic example of 'pausing' during the dialogue


To summarise what this project does:

[item] The player can move about using the arrow keys thanks to its tile movement behavior. When the Z key is pressed and the player is overlapping an NPC, a dialogue is initiated. The dialogue layer becomes visible, revealing the text box and the text is set in a typewrite style from the JSON.


[item] NPCs have an instance variable SceneId which dictates which 'scene' the dialogue is drawn from in the JSON file. There is also an instance variable to track how many times the player has spoken to the NPC - this is then used to change which scene is picked from the JSON file.


[item]When the Z key is pressed again, the next line is displayed - this is achieved by adding 1 to the curDialogue variable before calling the dialogue function. When we've reached the max number of lines in a specific scene, an End function is called. 


[item]Dialogue lines also have basic formatting thanks to a function that replaces formatting marks in the JSON file with their appropriate replacements (eg. /br to newline)

events.name: curDialogue
events.comment: The ID number of the current line of dialogue being displayed

events.name: curScene
events.comment: The ID number of the scene from which dialogue is being drawn

events.name: GameState
events.comment: The state of the game - used to determine when dialogue is being shown

events.name: NextLine
events.comment: Used for debugging - shows what the next line of dialogue will be

events.name: PlayerName
events.comment: An example variable to demonstrate using a replace expression to show variables in dialogue

events.text: When the layout starts, request the JSON project file and load it into the JSON object

actions.text: Mapping functions allows them to be called from a string stored in the JSON file used for dialogue

events.text:
When the game is in the "Dialogue" state, disable TileMovement to stop the player moving during the conversation.
As a simple example of 'pausing' while dialogue is being displayed, setting the [b]PauseTest[/b] object's time scale to 0 will stop it moving.
When no state is set, enable TileMovement to allow the player to move and restore the [b]PauseTest[/b] object's time scale to normal.
This event block controls the interaction button - used to call and progress dialogue. In this case, the [b]Z key.[/b]

children.text: When the Z key is pressed and the player is overlapping an NPC object, the dialogue mechanism will be triggered

When the GameState is not [b]Dialogue[/b] we set the curScene to one of the NPC's SceneId variables to pick the right part of the JSON file to call the text from. Then set the GameState to Dialogue to begin displaying text
If the [b]MultiLine[/b] boolean is set to false, we only use the one SceneID variable
If [b]MultiLine[/b] is set to true, then the number of times the player has spoken to the NPC dictates which SceneID to use.

When in the Dialogue state, add one to curDialogue to get the correct line from the JSON file and call the DisplayDialogue function. By adding the [b]is NOT running typewriter[/b] condition, we ensure that the player cannot skip through all the text by spamming the Z key.

[b]curDialogue's[/b] default value is -1 to ensure that we always started with the line with an ID of 0 (the first line in the scene)
The JSON file now has a key called [b]"Type"[/b] this defines what kind of line is being called from the JSON and then calls the correct function
If the value for curDialogue is one larger than the number of lines in the specific dialogue, call the EndDialogue function
When the Z key is pressed and the player is overlapping an NPC object, the dialogue mechanism will be triggered

If the [b]MultiLine[/b] boolean is set to false, we only use the one SceneID variable
If [b]MultiLine[/b] is set to true, then the number of times the player has spoken to the NPC dictates which SceneID to use.

When in the Dialogue state, add one to curDialogue to get the correct line from the JSON file and call the DisplayDialogue function. By adding the [b]is NOT running typewriter[/b] condition, we ensure that the player cannot skip through all the text by spamming the Z key.

[b]curDialogue's[/b] default value is -1 to ensure that we always started with the line with an ID of 0 (the first line in the scene)
The JSON file now has a key called [b]"Type"[/b] this defines what kind of line is being called from the JSON and then calls the correct function
If the value for curDialogue is one larger than the number of lines in the specific dialogue, call the EndDialogue function

events.text: Allows the player to display all dialogue using the desired key (SKIP DIALOGUE

children.text: This function is used to apply formatting and to add variable values to the text strings being displayed. The formatted text is returned as a string to be used in an expression

actions.text: Parameter "string" is passed in a replace() expression that turns any encounter of "/br" into a line jump, any "(b)" into "[ b]" (without the space) and "(/b)" into "[ /b]" (without the space) etc. This is BBCode that cannot be put as is in the JSON file, and if we put the proper tags into these comments, you'd just see the formatting!
Not only can replace() expressions be used for formatting, they can also be used to insert variables into the dialogue. Change the global variable PlayerName to test this.

children.text: This function counts the number of lines in the current scene and returns that number as a value to be used as an expression
This is the standard dialogue function. It displays the dialogue layer, sets the current line and next line according to the parameters dialogueID and sceneID and starts the typewriter text.

An altered version of the DisplayLine function only called when the JSON [b]"type"[/b] equals [b]"function"[/b]

Depending on what sort of function you're calling within the dialogue, you may not need to set the [b]Dialogue[/b] layer to invisible. Try toggling that event to disabled and see what works best for your game.
Similar to the above function [b]DisplayFunction[/b], this function will allow you to trigger a [b]Timeline[/b] based on a string stored in the JSON file.
This function ends the dialogue - it hides the dialogue layer, adds one to the TimesSpokenTo variable and resets both the GameState and curDialogue variables
This function is mapped to the string MoveHeart - it is called during one of the NPC conversations.
The JSON file now has a key called [b]"Type"[/b] this defines what kind of line is being called from the JSON and then calls the correct function
If the value for curDialogue is one larger than the number of lines in the specific dialogue, call the EndDialogue function
Animate the phone then tapped
